number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2012
												Takes everything from the original and makes it better. Instead of using a talent tree that costs gold per map to upgrade, there is a persistent upgrade system. You are rewarded skulls for finishing a level that you use to upgrade your traps, weapons and accessories. Being able to respec for free between maps adds a great deal of flexibility and promotes teamwork in the new co-op modes. All 3 game modes can be played co-op and the monster spawns are adjusted accordingly, leading to different strategies for SP & co-op.Both this and the original are cheap and worth picking up. Do you like killing orcs with guns, bows, hammers, traps, pets, or even magic? Then this is the game for you!

content:
Posted: January 29, 2013
												It's a tower defense game where the player does more damage than the towers (which are actually traps).  The traps have limited damage output, so it falls to the player to do most of the damage.What I like is how well this game separates solo from co-op.  In solo, you'll fight fewer (but not too few) orcs, and have access to up to 9 traps at once.  While in co-op, each player will have up to only 6 traps, meaning good teamwork is required.  Each character has some unique items/traps, while there is a large range of "general" traps that both characters will have.Overall a very solid game, and very fun when done with a friend.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												I only give this game a Negative review because of one thing...it's multiplayer only. Yes, I know you can play it on single player, but you're playing on multiplayer difficulty. The whole game was designed for co-op, not SP. It becomes an endless, overwhelming grind trying to battle the Orcs by yourself. There is no way to defend 2 doors with 4 portals spewing enemies alone. I got into OMD watching SSOHPKC's playthrough of it on his channel and I loved that game. It was hard, but fun. It was balanced, well thought out...this, nah...they just made one side of a level and mirrored it, you can clearly see it was made for co-op. Which is fine for people who have 50 friends on their list and have people to play it with, but I don't. Even the traps are kind of lacking. You'd think a regular Orc walking through a row of 10 poisoned spikes would kill it, but apparently not. And, there's so little place to put stuff, most of the walls have bumpy's that won't allow wall traps, ceilings are too high up to use ceiling traps, all you're left with is goo and spikes along with Guardians. Well good luck with that. The barricades are useless due to the fact that Boomers blow them up in less than a second. The costs are too high also. They even up'd the cost of most basic and useful trap(Goo) by 50 points. But anyway, like I said, despite it's flaws it's still a good game. IF, you have someone to play it with. That's the one major fun killer of this game, no real balanced single player. Otherwise, it would have been a yes recommendation.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												THIS IS A SINGLEPLAYER ONLY REVIEW!Let me start by saying that the game is not meant for singleplayer. In fact its almost unplayable in singleplayer! Most of the maps are made for two players, you can handle the easier ones on your own but not later on when the orcs comes from several directions at once! The game doesnt substitute for only one player, which means that you wont get enough money and you wont be able to cover everything on your own! I mean, just look at the steam page pictures, do you see any singleplayer pictures? They completely ignored those who perfer to play singleplayer. There is too much grinding involved too. To unlock everything you need to collect thousands of skulls, which would be fun in coop but not in singleplayer im afraid!Now to the really bad part:The traps are weak and expensive, the barricades are usless, they last for two rounds and then gets destroyed. All the fun in custom pathways is completely ruined by this! The weapons are boring and repetetive. The crossbow only works if you hit the head now? And some enemies are too powerful, just blasting through your traps making them useless for half a minute so the swarm can overrun you easily. Since the traps are useless and the enemies are overpowered you will be forced to do everything yourself. you wont be able to just sit back and see the orcs getting slaughtered by your trapmaking like a good defence game would. And that takes the fun out of this game completely! You can probably have fun after youve upgraded everything but why should i have to WORK in a GAME just to have simple fun?You should stick with Orcs Must Die 1 if you are a singleplayer guy!

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												This is effectively Orcs Must Die! 1.5.  There are new additions, but they are not much.The new additions include:Playing as the sorceress. (you can't switch between the sorceress and the warmage, each requires a new, separate, save.  also, some traps are unique to the character)Some new traps. (as expected)Some new enemies. (as expected)Endless mode. (aka grinding for skulls)Levels of upgrades for the trap. (necessitating the aformentioned grinding for skulls)Co-op. (aka, sacrificing the game on the bloody altar of co-op.  the game is now balanced for two players, so expect a serious spike in difficulty in the second act.  a single player can overcome this with lots of grinding for skulls to buy the traps and upgrade them.)If you liked the first one, go for it.  If you have not played the first one, get that instead.  This one is just more of the same, aimed at the co-op crowd.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This game is an absolute bargain! Firstly, I'll go over the improvements over the first game. First of all, we have the skull purchase system. After you comlete a level, based on an array of criterea, you are given a skull rating. These skulls are all added to your tally. You may then head over to the shop and spend these skulls on whatever you choose! This shop includes tons of traps, a large number of weapons and a good number of trinkets. Trinkets are new too, they provide passive and active bonuses, but normally do not directly affect combat with the horde. You may think that with that much content for this price, everything is just a reskin. Nope! There are tons of new traps, all varying dramatically from eachother. The weapons are all viable in their own ways, I haven't found anything to be straight up the best. Basically, tons of content that will leave you "staying for one more minute to get that next trap". Also, nothing is too overpriced, so there is very little grinding. Three levels max will get you that new piece of expensive gear to try out. By the way, some items are locked so you have to unlock them by beating a level. We don't want you getting the good stuff too soon! Finally, tons of upgrades! Every trinket, weapon and trap has a nice line of upgrades to further customise your play. My personal favourite trap is the haymaker, a spinning bar that comes down from the ceiling to deal damage and push the orcs around. I upgraded it to make it literally throw the orcs up into the air, sometimes to their deaths, which just makes the game that much more fun!Secondly, CO-OP! This is easily the best part of this game, now you can join in the orc slaying action with a friend! It is perfectly balanced, with all "money" earned being evenly split between players. However, always keep an eye out for that bonus skull that sometimes pops up after killing an enemy. Both players can see them, and me and my friend have had great races across the map to get us one step closer to that expensive weapon. Everything is better with friends, and Orcs Must Die 2 is exponentially so.I'll cover the rest on this paragraph. First of all, we have a new character, the sorceress. She has unique traps of her own, unobtainable by the classic War Mage, but he has his unique traps too. With some very interesting and often humerous dialogue between the rivals, it provides a great bit of story telling without drifting from the main content: killing Orcs. Another great addition to Orcs Must Die 2 is the secondry fire. Every weapon has primary and secondry fire modes, with the secondry providing a nice effect at the cost of a bit of mana. I'm pretty sure you can upgrade every weapons secondry fire, so you can find what fits you and make it the best it can be!Overall, It's just a blast. Especially at the Â£6 it is during this Holiday sale, you really can't go wrong with Orcs Must Die 2.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Having played through the game entirely with THREE different friends, I can now say that I think this game is the current standard for the tower-defense/fps hybrid genre.  The interface (extremely important in this genre) is very good, the gameplay is smooth, the characters are funny and interesting, and the story even makes enough sense to pay attention.  I highly recommend it over other td hybrids such as Deathtrap or Sanctum, though those games have some merit as well.The game's main problem is that in order to unlock all of the traps and empower them properly, you have to play the game through many times, or endure boring grinds.   Because you can refund your trap decisions at any time for free, this seems like a pointless mechanic which amounts to a pile of bookkeeping every time you wish to change strategies.  Skulls should come at a rate several times what they drop at in the game, because the game should be (and is for the most part) about your strategy and choices of traps per level, not what trap perks you happened to have unlocked at any given moment.  This is especially true since, with a little annoying click-through processing, you can rearrange your trap features anyway.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												SO is this game Worth the cash? In a word YES> If you liked the first One, you'll love this one. If you like Tower Defense, you'll enjoy thios game. If you enjoyed Dungeon Defenders, Defense Grid, or Sanctum you'll Love this game. Even if you've never played those other games this game is still worth the cash. Though be warned, this game will shift your alignment towards the darkside.The game takes the standard Tower defense mechanic and adds a few twists. You set traps to 'strongly deter' the orc hordes from their goal.  Kill more orks, get money, get money, Buyt more traps. Winde variety of enemies, wide variety of traps  and the ability to get into the fray when things get hectic.CHallenging, FUn, FUnny and will  A LOT of replayability.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------PROS HIGH Replayability. With different difficulty settings, Endless mode,  Traps Gear, Two playable Characters/classes and even a regularly updated special weekly challenge. You'll be playing this game for a while. That's to say nothing about the Mods. Simple Mechanics, High depth., The mechanics are fairly simple and it's very easy to see and gauge the actions of each trap. How you approach any given level depends on not only which class but which set of traps you take in. Some combinations make things easy but there always harder and different ways if you like to experiment and challenge yourself The Story actually continues from the first one but strangely they do it in such away that not playing the first one will not leave you in the dark.  THe oneliners and dialogue between the War Mage and Sorceress between missions is genuinely funny and clever. CONS: I really can't think of any cons beyond that it can get a little repetitive at times but as said it's only as repetitive as your ability to experiment with new builds and tactics. If you don't like trying sub optimal or harder builds and simply approach it with a straight line ideology this game will get boring for you. If you're the type who likes to try new things, new tactics and new placements just for the heck of it or just to challenge yourself. You will love this game.THE AWESOME:Ragdoll physics! If you cannot find joy in using a giant swinging mace to knoick a bunch of orcs onto a bed of spiks. Or using a spring trap to catapult orcs half way across a room and ontro the bed of flaming brimstone you set up. You my friend are a sad sad individual.Should you get the first one. I actually recomend it. It's not entirely a step down from this. The advancement to two was more of a lateral than a linear advancement.  Oh There's also co-op multiplayer

number of helpful: 11 of 26 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												A nice game, through a combination of traps, weaponry, teamwork and planning you can smoothly run through the levels with a decent amount of challenge. Orcs range in size and ability to prevent things from getting dull too quickly.I can however not recommend this game for a simple reason. The base game does not provide enough content to justify the price, the amount of orcs you'll be fighting is limited at best (personally I think boring amounts). However through mods a lot of things can be rectified and made fun, the amount of content is astonoshing and the various overpowered mods (both for the players and the orcs) make it much more fun and give it a lot more gametime.Unfortunately the developers have rigged the game in such a way that adding even a single mod will prevent anything you do from being saved.You heard me right, no saves, no unlocks will be remembered, no level progress, NOTHING.Why? Well according to the devs it's to prevent people from installing "every unlock costs 0 gold"-mods and simply unlocking everything instantly. Personally I do not see the problem with that, some people prefer unlocking as they play, others prefer having everything from the start, and it certainly doesn't justify kicking mod support in the head for it.Obviously, if you're the kind of person who doesn't mind lack of proper mod support, go ahead an buy it, you'll have a great time for a few hours.If however, you're like me, you'll find this game is but a shell of what it can be with mods, and once you played with mods, you won't want to go back, but you'll be forced to go back because the game refused to safe otherwise.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												**Composite Score: 9.125/10** If you enjoyed the first game, you'll definitely enjoy the second. If you have fun with tower defense games which incorporate FPS elements, you'll enjoy this too.This game launched at $15 for a single copy or $25 for two. Or, if you got it during the Steam sale, $12.50/$22.50. That's really inexpensive for this quality of game. I definitely recommend picking it up at these prices f you're into this game genre. **Entertainment Value: 10/10** Solid excitement mixed with charming humor. I really enjoyed playing solo. Co-operative play really depends on who you're playing with and dealing with network/tech issues. My partner had some microphone and XBOX controller issues, so we had to deal with tech problems at the start. But, after we got those sorted, we had a good time roasting, slicing, and crushing waves of orcs. **Graphics: 9/10** The Vision engine still delivers as good of a product as it did in OMD!. On my SLI GTX 570 setup, I get solid graphics performance and appearance. Anti-aliasing and Anisotropic Filtering are both great. No artifacting at all. Only reason this doesn't get a 10 is that the traps often don't mesh perfectly with the surroundings. And, coins sometimes get lost behind walls. **Sound: 9/10** Solid sound like the first game. Music is lively and entertaining. The surround system works. The orcs still tell silly lines, and now that dwarves have been added, they enhance the humor too. I give this game a 9 instead of the standard 8, because the dialog and music enhance the experience better than most other low-budget games of this style. **Design and Gameplay: 9/10** Gameplay has been tweaked since OMD!. There are more weapons, trinkets, and a new female character, the sorceress. There are new monsters. There are other ways to play such as ENDLESS and Co-op. Also, the way players can upgrade traps and items is distinctly different from the first game.... somewhat more like an RPG than before. Otherwise though, it's still build traps and use your character's powers to defeat the waves of mosters before they exit the map. **Game Length: 9/10** Given the game's low price and its incorporated multiplayer mode, don't think too harshly about it taking me less than three hours to complete the first half of the campaign on War Mage (normal) difficulty. I'm not done with the second half yet, but I've spent a couple of hours doing and redoing the next few maps. Also, I've spent many more hours playing through ENDLESS maps, going for high-scores, and playing through the classic maps using the new trap upgrades and weapons. Therefore, I'm quite happy with the game's length.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												This is the first time writing a review I wish I had a middle thumbs option, because this game is a mixed bag. It is FUN, but it squanders it's full potential with some terrible designer choices that I will detail below. As another reminder, THIS GAME IS NOT BAD, it's just "meh":WHAT'S GOOD ABOUT THIS GAME? CO-OP - Primarily designed to be a co-op experience, this game certainly shines when you play with a friend. You have two different characters, the crazy mage lady and the dumb-happy miner mage, focused on mana and being a jack-of-all-trades respectively. Selection is nice to have, and synergizing towers is always fun GAMEPLAY - If you've played any other FPTD game, you know the gist of this. Round by round, you place towers and attack the incoming mobs at you. Absolutely no complaints here, it's as good as any other game. ORC VARIETY - There's enjoy variety in the incoming orcs to constantly keep you on your feet, be it a regular grunt, a quick-footed orclet, or a regenerating troll (or Mister Moneybags!) FUN - Above all else, this game was fun to play with a friend. It took 17 hours to finish the game with all maps five-skulled, and I don't regret a single one of those hours.WHAT'S MEDIOCRE ABOUT THIS GAME? STORY - The story is absolutely useless. It was interesting, and it probably would've helped if I had played the original game, but there definitely could've been more story. I got what was going on, but I eventually lowered the voice audio because I really didn't care. DIFFICULTY - The game really isn't that hard, even on the hardest difficulty. If you are looking to get a challenge out of this game, you've come to the wrong place.WHAT'S BAD ABOUT THIS GAME? BUILDINGS - Okay, get ready for this because I'm about to rip on Orcs Must Die! 2 This game only had 9 good/useful towers OUT OF 35. This is less than 1/3 of the buildings!This is completely unacceptable for a TD game! All the tower unlocks that you get get your hopes up for 2 minutes before you realize in-game that they rate of fire is too damn slow or too expensive to actually use. Compared to Sanctum 2 or Dungeon Defenders, utter crap. WEAPONS - Same thing with weapons! I didn't count, but only some 6 weapons were actually useful/useable in-game, which out of a list of ~20, is an utter disappointment. SKULL RESETTING - Want to remove a single trap pick? Good â¥â¥â¥â¥ing luck, because you'll be having to be resetting all 200 of your skulls and picking everything from scratch EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. Why on earth can you not have an individual remove individual selections?Compared to the Sanctum series and the Dungeon Defenders series, arguably the two most popular FPTD games on Steam, this game pales in comparison to them all. That's not to say that isn't fun for the time that you play it or that's objectively "bad", but if you had twenty dollars in your hand and you wanted to pick a FPTD game to get into, This should not be your first pick. Sanctum 2 > Dungeon Defenders > DD2 > Orcs=Sanctum6.5/10

number of helpful: 14 of 33 people (42%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												While i do recommend this game and it is fun to buy and level up traps, the game does have one real flaw. it doesn't really have a replay value, and i find that you start to rely on the same old traps due to having to level them up to be useful. While the storyline is interesting and the game is quite fun, once i beat the game i felt very little desire to replay even on the endless modes. Once you fully level up a trap, its very useful and its hardpressed to replace it with a lesser trap without grinding out the required skulls to get the new trap leveled up to be usefull. The weapons can make the game more difficult, and its rarley a good choice to use anything that drains magic, the 'powerful' abilities of the magic items make them less then effective. often you have to use more then one weapon, limiting the amount of traps you can have. Over all the game is a blast, but with little to no return value in the end.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2012
												Everything the fantastic OMD is and then some.  Online co-op of course being the big addition.  Despite reused assets, notably some music and later level themes - there's now 2 characters, a greater assortment of traps, weapons and vastly expanded skull-based upgrade system, where skulls can now be earned in various ways, including drops from mobs mid-game.  The base game has fewer maps than OMD, however owning the first adds 10 more classic levels, DLC then adds 9 more (at 3 a piece) plus new weapons, trinkets and traps and a few extra maps for the gruelling endless mode.   Good wholesome orc slaughter, with a gleeful grin and dash of strategy makes this some of the most engaging co-op action going, as you team up to let the orcs have it, "RIGHT IN THE FACE!".

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												Tower defense genre is very dear to me, but there is a lot of dev teams that just copy paste generic ideas from others, most time failing at that.Robot Entertainment managed to create a unique game within the TD genre, which is quite an achievement, they have introduced a very nice mix of FPS action and Tower Defense planning. You place towers then play out the role of a hero and you can see how effective your tower placement is, what helps you in your fight and what does not so that you can potentially improve next time. The little bits of lore, environments and monsters may not be entirely unique but are done with style, their own style which I do appreciate. OMD1 and OMD2 are a must for any tower defense games fan.What has happened that the devs decided to go with some stupid moba-like variation of OMD i have not idea but I really hope they will release a continuation of OMD 1 or 2.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Not a step up  from the first game by any means.The level design is worse, there are sidetracks which are annoying to reach.The balance is kind of off, it feels like it's been balanced for co-op. On some maps it feels like you kill 90% percent of the enemies with your weapons instead of the traps, because you don't have enough money. This is supposed to be a tower defense game, not a shooter.The progress by which you earn your traps is not ideal, sometimes you can only get a certain trap right after the one map you would have really needed it, so you have to replay the map to get all the skulls: voila! Artificial game length padding...The new weapons are boring, the new traps unneccessary, and the trinkets? I've rarely even added them to my loadout...The only worthy addition is that you can upgrade your traps, but other than that, this game does nothing better than the first one.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												The game itself is fun and could prove very addicting, but I do not recommend it for a one good reason (I myself regret buying this game for myself and my friend) - the coop is broken with bad game design and net code. Orcs must die 2 is all about 2 person coop, almost every map has like two (or more) hallways, two rifts, two orc spawn points etc, so its the most fun when played with a friend, however most of the time you get random disconnects without any reason and without a save point or a chance to reconnect. It is rarely a problem during most of the story missions as they are short, but if you play other modes like endless, it could take 1 or 2 hours to complete, and any second you could just get a message popping up, saying that there is a connection trouble and then it just redirects you to the main menu, so you will have to start the level from the beggining. If you check official forums, you will see that MANY people have this problem, and devs just can not fix it.So if you just want to have some solo fun killing orcs with many different traps and weapons to help you - go ahead and buy this game, but if you plan on playing coop like the game is designed to, don't waste your money, coop is basically unplayable.Cheers.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												DO NOT BUY IF YOU'RE A CONTROLLER PLAYER - YOU'VE BEEN WARNED!!!Trash.  Devs apparently became lazy and liars between OMD and OMD2.  For over a year they've been "fixing the issue and adding in proper controller support," and they never got around to getting it taken care of.  That's what my research for a fix for this issue turned up.  No one's managed to ever figure this one out.  The controller support, oddly for Xbox nonetheless, isn't present - even though they listed it as having full controller support in Steam.The Xbox controller, at random, tends to permanently come up as an improperly mapped gaming mouse.  No matter how many times I exit and relaunch the game, even after a reboot and disabling my firewall, this crap game still fails to detect the controller as what it actually is...a controller.  I wish someone had the clout to get them to focus on fixing this issue now instead of pushing out yet another game they clearly aren't ready for yet.This is an issue with the programming of the game, not anything else.  Most players can simply plug and play without a problem.  The minority group, even though it isn't a very small group, cannot.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Here is why I CANNOT recommend this to ANYONE: I will tell this in the form of a "good-news-and-bad-news" message.The Good News:"Orcs Must Die! 2" has a Steam Workshop and there's even a modding tool available for it.The Bad News:If you're playing a modded game, then guess what: not only does it not put your score up on the Leaderboards (which I wouldn't mind, and is understandable); it ALSO will NOT save your progress AT ALL! This means that if you use even a COSMETIC mod in your game (such as the Princess Leia Slave Outfit), then you will find that your game DID NOT save your progress the next time you open the game! Indeed, this reminds me of the plight of Sisyphus!According to Greek mythology, Sisyphus is a king who's being punished for eternity in the Underworld. His punishment: he must push a boulder up a huge mountain; and just when he and the boulder are almost at the top of that mountain, the boulder slips from his grasp; and it rolls all the way to the bottom of the mountain!Because of this SISYPHIAN game policy of not saving the progress of modded games, I BEG you, reader, to tell all of your friends, their brothers, their sisters, their fathers, their mothers, and their pets NOT to purchase this game!Oh, and one more thing: if you start playing "Orcs Must Die! Unchained" (which is an upcoming free-to-play sequel to this game), then PLEASE, and I cannot emphasize this enough... PLEASE don't pay microtransactions of ANY kind! Not only that, but please do me a big favor by telling everyone you see in that particular game to ALSO not make any microtransactions in "Orcs Must Die! Unchained", and you might also want to ask your fellow OMD!U players not to buy this game or the original "Orcs Must Die!". This way, we can work together to hit ROBOT where it hurts: their Net Income!

number of helpful: 1 of 10 people (10%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												I'm a huge tower defense fan. There are a lot of ways to make a game like this, and in some ways, this is one of the strongest versions of TD I've ever played. It has a lot of ways to experiment, it has weapon and enemy interactions which aren't just raw math and a matter of course--so you have an opportunity to think outside the box and really explore interesting ways to solve the puzzle of beating various waves and difficulties.But there are two TD mechanisms that really bug me and make me lose interest. They're both related to the idea of building the walls that push the enemies around the map. In a game where you get to build walls, the route you design for the enemy to take is a big part of the game and the puzzle.First, you don't get the piece that lets you make a wall until you've played for several levels. I encountered a bug where my progress wasn't being saved, and as a result, I had to play the same several levels over and over again to get access to this piece. Also, the wall pieces initially cost a ludicrous amount. When you upgrade them, they cost less, though, only with a mod, do they cost an amount that makes designing paths through the level at all interesting. Otherwise they just seem to take away money better spent on damage dealing traps--in which case, why bother?Second, the wall pieces do not consistently work. While I'm a fan of physics adding an unpredictable element to a game, when you can't be guaranteed that your walls will even work at all in some circumstances, I get really frustrated. Again--if walls don't work consistently, why have that element at all? Just make me place aggressive defenses, then. Or use the model (That they've incorporated) of putting down friendly units which move around and tie up the enemies.They have everything in the kitchen sink here, and I think they leaned too heavily on RPG mechanics, both in terms of holding back all the cool stuff you could play the game with, and in terms of being dogmatically rock-paper-scissors about how all the traps work to the extent that there is a monster 'counter' to walls (and I'm not talking about flying--I'm talking about running units who can climb over barriers and do so inconsistently, as well as normal units that just glitch over the barriers--there's also exploding units which destroy your built traps, which as a mechanism would be interesting, but, again, they can cross barriers which means you can't deal with them by building deep--you have to hope you shoot them in time, or a ranged trap--which you don't initially get, thanks to the RPG style gating--gets them). I'd like it if you had access to all traps, and the monsters didn't arbitrarily run over walls, but had to destroy their way through them consistently, unless they were fliers.

												Orcs Must Die! 2 is a solid game, as far as hybrid tower defense goes. However, it never managed to, ah, grab my attention. It just felt very same ol, same ol. Not particularly difficult. 												I don't know about the co-op... but the overall game is not nearly as well designed as the original. I constantly found myself wishing I had trap x, y, or z. You only get traps at the end of levels or when you buy them (in between levels). This can easily leave you without what you need as every level is designed or a variety of traps. This offers more replayability, but the grind to get there simply isn't enjoyable. I recommend playing the first game instead. Each level is built with specific traps in mind (traps you are given).

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

												A whole lot of fun, without a whole lot of commitment.This is best played with a friend, and I played through the fair length campaign level list in a couple of hours. The game is about replayability, though, and if you manage to get through the first couple of levels, you may find that you don't have a problem replaying some for more unlockable stuff.I couldn't follow the story, really, but the main characters are funny, and hearing the same voiceover 100 times didn't get as grating as you'd think.If you play endless mode, right around Wave 45, things get a little ridiculous!

												I love this game. The levels change enough that finding and making "cheap" combos is actually required to win on harder difficulties. Physics, trap options, and teamwork mechanics make it by far better and less formulaic than dungeon defenders.

Overall I'd give this a solid 8/10.

												This is a very great game. Not only is it funny, this game can only seem to get better and better. First the core game, then Are We There Yeti?, then Family Ties, THEN Fire and Water, and NOW this game has Steam Workshop support. Pop some Orcs with a Blunderbuss, and you'll feel damn good too.

Give the demo a try, THESE ORCS MUST DIE!

content:
Posted: August 23, 2012
												The original Orcs Must Die was FANTASTIC. Stemming the wave was absolutely ingenious fun, and this sequel streamlines the traps system, adds multiplayer, AND finally gives your Ashley J. Williams-inspired protagonist a Boomstick.I love that the light sense of dangerous fun between the Warmage and the Sorceress is still intact, and that the nature of what you're being asked to do is as ridiculous as ever. Half the fun of Orcs Must Die was its' aesthetic - which is as brilliant as ever.  I hope they port over the rest of OMD 1's levels, and allow endless with the classic maps.Ok, that's enough listening to me.  Go kill Orcs!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I had a lot of fun with this game both with my friend and on my own, even if the reason I started playing on my own was because my friend hated me after we played this game.In all seriousness, this game is a great blend of strategy and fast-paced FPS, and it's pretty fun to play with a friend planning traps and killing orcs. It would be nice if I could play with more than just one friend, but there's so many games with 4 player coop anyway, and most don't work well with just 2 people.So yeah, get this game if you want a fast paced shooter mixed with a tower defense RTS that you can play with a friend for hours until they hate you and quit.

This game is a 3rd person tower defense/brawler in my eyes, and having completed it on a friends computer, I still can't get enough.Pros- The traps are hilarous to watch, especially the spring trap that launches foes flying.The writing is witty, though short, and funny.Map layout is varied and intersting, I have never had a similar expierence from any other maps, pushing the use of certain traps.The replayability is extremely high in my eyes because of its weekly challenges and endless modes, as well as the strive to collect all the skullsCo-op is the best part, where teamwork can create some of the funniest chain traps ever, making it hard to beat the level when you are laughing so hardThis game is intense and fast paced, something I greatly enjoy as it creates an rush down your spine as you sprint around trying to protect my riftsCons- Gun play for me was very awkward with some ranged weapons, where I found my shots hitting orcs, but not doing damageAll the DLC for me is also a problem, as there are 3 dlcs so far, and when all combined, they total the same amount as the gamePlaying single player doesn't give the full expierence of the gameIn the end, I find this a buy for me and too all as well. I have heard that Orcs Must Die 2 is like Dungeon Defenders, but saying that is like comparing a milkshake to spoiled milk, it doesn't serve the justice this game deserves.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Oh Orcs Must Die! 2...what can I say after way too many hours of playing?Pro:1) Great mixture of Tower Defense and 3rd Person ShooterYou really have to think of a strategy for every level and, especially when playing the Sorceress there are hardly levels where the same strategy works twice. This is a really nice change from OMD 1. So you have to use your brain in every level. The third person shooter part adds nicely to it as you cannot lean back in the beginning and your very own skills are also needed.2) Co-op!You can play with a friend in this one and especially for Nightmare and Endless it is a load of fun, especially when aiming for high scores or just randomly picking traps and weapons and seeing how far you get.3) ReplayabilityCollecting skulls, getting high scores, beating the map with War Mage and Sorceress, trying new combinations of traps and so on and so forth....you can replay a level a hundred times and it will hardly ever get boringCons:1.) Co-opYes, this is a Pro, but especially in War Mage and if one of the players is experienced, Co-op gets old and boring rather fast as it offers no real challenge. Even Nightmare can get too easy. So personally, I think there should've been an additional mode or something comparable to make Co-op a little more challenging.2.) No real changesOMD 1 was great. OMD 2 is great. But there are hardly any REAL changes. Half of the game even uses the same general map layout as the first game. I'd love to see differences and new experiments, maybe commanding the Orcs for a while or something.Conclusion:Especially during a Sale you just cannot go wrong with the game. You can use the demo to try it out and see for yourself whether or not you like it, too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												If you're in the mood for tactical combat, well planned defenses and fighting against hordes of intelectual enemies... You're out of luck. But, if you're looking for hilarious hack and slash combat, teamed up with traps, dudes, and different weapons, all the while fighting a nearly endless onslaught of orcs, trolls, and all kinds of other nasties, then Orcs Must Die! 2 is your game. I've played it, I love it. Lots of things to do, no two situations are the same, and the ability to place and even upgrade your traps and emplacements makes the game a lot more personable. It's got witty comedy, sketch humor, and slapstick built in, and the best yet, tons of different game objectives that revolve around killing orcs. Two player, and personable = a good game to me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												OK, after almost 600 hours in this game (Its my most played title) you prob know I'm gonna say ITS FREAKIN' AWESOME!! I've always been a fan of Tower Defense games with Defense Grid being my former #1 choice. (Peeved I did all those hours at Onlive and they're not reflected here). I actually didnt think it got better than that (and for true TDefense DG is #1) but OMD2 ups the game by PUTTING YOU IN THE GAME!! You not only set traps and watching them work but the majority of your success is dependent on your 3rd person skills combat. This game is so much fun and has so much replayabilty its CRazY!!You often replay maps until you DOMINATE them.  Then there are the Endless modes. The very nice DLC's, Coop and more. The beauty of the game is the fact that any level can be solved in a variety of ways. Different trap combos and placement can have wildy varying results. The art style is fun and the two avatars are different enough that its worth playing the game fully 2X just to max out each toon. The need to 5 skull each level (max points) can become an obsession especially since the diff between winning/losing can come down to a single mislaid trap. Even when you lose you never feel like the game cheated you. You always feel like "If I just did...'X', I would have won!!". If you like tower defense I can guarantee you'll like this game. Its a very unique spin on this popular game genre. Enjoy!! (I'm off to put a couple more hours into it...)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												The first time you play through a level is frantic, and often desparate. The highs are high and the defeats sting. But the controls are spot-on, and if you lose it's your fault. You will then revisit your favorite levels again and again, using your hard-won gear, your better sense of each level's layout, and a sense of what comes next to move your way up the leader boards. Plenty of replay value here. Trying to hit the enemy with as many different *kinds* of traps at the same time is key to high scores, and its a blast when you can pull it off. I haven't enjoyed a shooter this much since Doom II back in the day. The only important thing missing is a framework for player-made levels. (Players can only mod the waves, not the levels.)

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Orcs must die! 2 is a mix between Tower defence and third person shooter. Your goal is to stop the orcs from going into the rift. And to do that you Obviously have to place traps. You have a spellbook where you can unlock awesome traps and weapons by buying them with the skulls of the orcs! You can slow the orcs, you can freeze them, burn them, fling them into the abyss or even throw them into another dimension. You also have Guardians that will fight for you and kill as many orcs as they can until they die. Don't think that this is some boring old tower defence game where you just sit back and watch. No, you have weapons too that you have to kill the orcs with. Without you there is no hope.Orcs must die! 2 is a realy fun game with tons of action and humor. You never get bored of it :3Now go to the store and buy it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												The first Orcs Must Die was a funny, challenging, inventive barrel of fun. The second is much of the same quality but with the one feature that was most sorely missed from the first installment: Co-op gameplay. The addition of this feature, as well as a huge multitude of traps, customisation, and a larger library of levels, makes OMD2 superior to its predecessor in every way. A larger variety of enemies helps to keep you on your toes and to change strategies in the middle of battle. As always the central feature of the game is building your maze of death. Killing hordes of orcs with all the different traps is just as sadistically cathartic as it was before. Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												This game is pretty fun.I'm sure this would only be fun as a multiplayer game. I play with friends and it can be very interesting, considering its like a first person tower defense game. You have a toon with weapons you can choose to upgrade. You also have an inventory of traps you can pay for which are laid down along the pathways that the Orc's will follow. This is pretty fun because it is a 3rd person shooter, with the strategies of placing traps on the floors, walls and ceilings. Not to mention your weapons can get pretty sweet. Its also very chill. The game speed is not too fast to make it a super tight tower defense game, but just fast enough to be entertained without spilling your drink all over your desk. I recommend this game to anyone who likes the strategy beat-em-up's. Its worth it for the experience. I got this game when it was on sale. It's currently listed for $14.99 which I think is a little much for the content, but it is an excellent game nontheless. 8/10

												Orcs Must Die! 2 is both very enjoyable and rather challenging. It is a combination of both Tower Defense and 3rd Person Action. There are 2 playable characters; a Male and Female. Each kill you make in it is very satisfying, the defenses are upgradable, and thre is a good few hours of gameplay (Im 1/2 done campaign at 6 hrs, and i still have some other non story levels to do, excluding DLC). Alot of people sa "Dungeon defenders" is better, but i personally think Orcs Must Die! 2 is a welcome addition to any library, and will keep you entertained for a few days.+Good combat with cool weapons and traps+Lots of level types+Lots of enemies-Not really a gripping story-There is only 2 playable characters (Although there are different skins)Good overall singleplayer, great with mates. 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												A tower defense and a third-person shooter are mixed together in this game, where the objective is as simple as it could be: Orcs Must Die! As you go through either multiplayer or singleplayer you will receive skulls based on your performance, which you can spend to unlock anything from a Tar Trap to the truly hilarious Spring Trap, as well as weapons, trinkets and even costumes! Whats even better is that you are able to upgrade and choose a special ability for all of your orc-killing arsenal, making sure that you will be able to play the game over and over again, and still have a new layout for your traps, or a new set of traps to test out together. You are also able to choose from 2 heroes, both of which have traps and weapons that the other doesnt. Altogether, this game is one of best games Ive ever played, even though I barely played it at all. If I had to give this a score, it would be 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												As the tower defense genre has gotten more popular there have been many games that have added to or improved upon the formula. This has allowed the genre to stay relatively fresh and not to become a tired trend. The original Orcs Must Die provided the interesting spin of not only forgoing the towers completely in exchange for traps, but putting the player directly into the fray themselves. Orcs Must Die 2 successfully adds to this formula in a number of ways.The goal of Orcs Must Die 2 is to protect the rift points of each level from the invading orcs and other creatures. First, the player must choose between the Warmage and the Sorceress, both with their own unique ability. Players are given a set number of slots for them to bring both weapons and traps. Some players may prefer to try their hand with minimal traps, while others will rely on them almost exclusively. As players progress through the game, they will be thrown new enemies, forcing them to adapt their strategies on each level. Based on their performance, players earn skulls, which allow them to unlock new traps, weapons, and even outfits for their character. Arguably, the largest addition is the cooperative multiplayer. Instead of taking on the hordes of orcs alone with a single loadout, you can now play with one other person, each with their own specific loadouts. This encourages teamwork in a number of ways. Strategic combinations of traps allow the duo to rack up combos, affording them more currency to place more traps or hanging onto the currency to get a better rating, and thus more skulls,  at the end of the level. Picking weapons that work well together allow for clearing out any stragglers that get past the traps or simply an easier time for those who prefer the more hands-on approach. The levels are appropriately sized for what's asked of the player. Many of the larger levels also give players shortcuts to different areas, ensuring they have ample time to respond to each wave of enemies that appears if they have a good strategy. While the perfect strategy might not be stumbled upon immediately, after a couple of tries the various choke points in the levels become more obvious with a couple of exceptions. Many levels also incorporate special traps of their own for the player to utilize, simply adding to the fun and strategy of a given place. Different enemies with different weaknesses encourage the player to use a variety of traps and weapons to find the playstyle that suits them best. While the option does exist to go heavy on the weapons, it's clear the game was designed around the use of both traps and weapons for a player to progress very far. This means only the most skilled third-person action players will have any chance at all of beating levels without the heavy use of traps.The art style and mixed rock soundtrack add a lot to the game's atmosphere and personality, which is far from serious. The Warmage and Sorceress bust into breakdancing after a particularly good performance. Sarcastic and humurous quips are constantly dropped by the heroes. Orcs and other enemies make exclamations about wanting their mother while they are chewed to bits by a wall grinder or other nefarious device. The amount of violence is large, but the exaggerated proportions of both the heroes and enemies leads to it not being disturbing to teenagers and adults.While Orcs Must Die 2 can be played alone, it is painfully obvious that is not the way the game is designed. Solo orcslayers will have a hard time making meaningful progression, especially in the higher difficulty settings. Large numbers of enemies, in combination with some of the more complex levels, makes micromanaging the stages without one defined choke point more of a chore than fun. This difficulty is greatly eased with the presence of a co-op partner. It's hard to recommend the game as a solo experience given the huge artificial spike in difficulty thanks to the game's focus. Certain levels crank the difficulty level up far too high past what was in the previous stage. Even with a co-op partner, most players will run into some of these stages like a brick wall that require a lot of frustration and annoyance to climb over. The story is bare minimum, and while not terrible, only really serves as an excuse for the chaos going on within the game's universe. Most players likely won't have an issue with this, but the game is not for those looking for a narrative heavy experience.Despite its flaws, Orcs Must Die 2 is incredibly fun and addictive. The thrill of getting five skulls on a level that has become the bane of your existence is hard to beat. With a friend, the game is guaranteed to provide you with hours of amusement and fun, even long after you've beaten the campaign, as long as you can deal with the steep difficulty spikes you encounter.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												This game is pretty amazing I have to say. I got 2 copies while it was on sale so I'd have someone to play it with, it came with all the expansions as well. The game is silly at times which is fine, the traps have a fun range to them and the coop makes it really fun. It also has mod support so people have changes some of the underwelming weapons and traps to make them better. Pros: Overall fun gameplay.Quite a few traps to have fun with.CoopA good selection of maps.Decent amount of comedy.Quite a few mobs to have to plan around.Traps are viscious and creating a gauntlet of death to watch them squirm through is a special kind of joy.Though I don't own the first game (so I can't compare this to it) it seems that if you do own it you can play the maps from that game in coop as there is a classic maps option.Cons:Some of the traps are kind of lame in their vanilla state (can be changed with mods though) for example, the void portal, it can't do anything by itself so you need to set it up with other traps to get enemies into it, it's freaking massive so finding a place to put the thing is is difficult, the ability to summon skeletons of the mobs that you throw in is cool in theory but they rarely spawn and they seem to die as soon as they're out of combat. Another example is the coinforge in my opinion, it's big and takes up alot of floor space that you could be using for other traps and all for, what I'd consider, a minor effect.Similarly some of the weapons seem underpowered, or overpowered, the dwarvern hammer can stunlock loads of people for easy kills, meanwhile the wind belt can't seem to kill anything directly and relies on throwing people off cliffs.All of the things I'd consider cons are really fixable by checking out the mods people made to fix the traps and such that are under-used, the game is 100% worth picking up in my opinion, especially if it's on sale. Was worth every cent.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I was bummed out that they nerfed the crossbow and broke the headshot registry, but there is a workaround of sorts... you just have to use the ice amulet to freeze the enemy and then headshots from the crossbow will register properly. Another annoying thing is if you want to try playing as the opposite character, you have to start from scratch. It would be nice if you could just switch your character at any time and have all your skulls intact. Co-op sounds good in theory but it's actually pretty awful unless you and your partner are completely intune with one another and you are both completely adept at playing.Even though it's not as good as the first one, there's still lots of fun to be had on the singe player campaign.

												Very good expansion on the original. Feels like it is much more geared to two player action though. Many of the levels are a pretty tough challange for a single player. The art style, trap variety and dialog are all excellent. Highly recommended for fans of tower defense and multiplayer action. If you only play single player games you may want to try the origional OMD first. Overall thumbs up! 85/100 on my scale

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												I've had a lot of fun with this game. It's a tower defense + first person shooter hybrid, but unlike games like Sanctum, the "tower" (trap) placement feels much more natural and intuitive. I've spent hours finding new, exciting and entertaining ways to kill orcs. Lots of traps, lots of weapons, lots of maps and lots of fun.

												Third-person, tower defense game and lots of fun. The co-op play works great. All DLCs are good, too. If I had to think of negatives, the story is sort of stupid and there is not endless content. If I hadn't finished all levels and upgrades, I would still be playing this game. 												Overall pretty decent game.Got it in the humble bundle awhile ago and didn't expect it to be that great, looked at some footage since it was just sitting there and decided to give it a go. The game isn't exactly addictive but it makes you want to progress due to the ease of the levels and the fact that you can customise your gear with upgrades.I recommend this game if its under Â£10 as it will give you something to do but I wouldn't say its a top priority purchase at all. If anything just a time killer if you need one.
